description: {"blocks":[{"key":"2oi30","text":"This document codifies the probe preparation of pyruvate and urea for dissolution dynamic nuclear polarization. Additionally, this also describes the steps recommended for estimation of T1 and polarization and quality assurance to ensure repeatability and robustness of hyperpolarized 13C probe formulation. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":285,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

document: {"blocks":[{"key":"1mlaq","text":"Contents","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rjf1","text":"I) General Remarks","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6j94u","text":"    a.Glassing and high compound concentration","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cblhr","text":"    b.Stability of compound formulations","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6i5jv","text":"II) Trityl Radicals","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"97n9f","text":"    a.Storage and handling","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e1925","text":"    b.Structures and molecular weights","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"44ut4","text":"III) Recipe of [1-13C]pyruvic acid and 13C Urea","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":18,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":39,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48b5j","text":"IV) Quality assurance (QA) procedure for hyperpolarized (HP) Formulations using Hypersense","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"12pjf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9u7ka","text":"I) General Remarks","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1osmd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4h8nu","text":"A. Glassing and high compound concentration","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4737n","text":"The highest levels of nuclear spin polarization and MR signal are attained when the 13C concentration is as high as possible.The ideal compound formulations therefore are small molecule liquids prepared neat.If needed, the compounds must be formulated with appropriate (co)solvents and at a concentration such that they reliably form an amorphous glass when cooled rapidly.Glassing is critical to achieve high levels of polarization.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":84,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ek7lb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fqb7h","text":"B. Stability of compound formulations","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hd4b","text":"The various compounds are stable to various degrees and the radicals are light sensitive.Formulated compounds are best stored frozen and protected from light. Gadolinium(III) chelates, e.g. Dotarem / Gd-DOTA, are relatively unstable at low pH, such as when dissolved in pyruvic acid, and will dissociate to free Gd3+ ions when in liquid state.This can have a significant negative impact on the T1 relaxation rate upon dissolution, which results in the hyperpolarized signal decaying faster.To summarize:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":60,"length":29},{"style":"sup","offset":314,"length":2},{"style":"sub","offset":395,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"40ntm","text":"Note:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fjbcj","text":"Protect from light exposure whenever possible","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f75ts","text":"Do not let compound formulations sit at room temperature for extended periods","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26n1u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jfsj","text":"II) Trityl Radicals","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9qih1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdmle","text":"A. The stabilized trityl radicals used as the source of spin polarization are costly and must be stored and handled properly.They are best stored long term cold, dry and protected from light, e.g. in a jar containing a dessicating agent in the freezer.To prevent the buildup of water condensation, allow them to warm to room temperature before handling.The trityl radicals are typically light, lyophilized solids of various shades of green.To reduce their tendency to cling to surfaces when handling them, it helps to use an antistatic gun to dissipate static electricity on the plasticware and weighing containers.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ctvct","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e1hvr","text":"B. The structures and molecular weights of the radicals:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5l4eu","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"evcu9","text":"       R =          Name         Formula         Molecular Weight            -CH2CH2OH         OX-63         C52H60Na3O18S12         1426.77            -CH2CH2OCH3         “GE Trityl” /   AH-111501          C64H84Na3O18S12         1595.09            -CH3         Finland         C40H36Na3O18S12         1066.46      ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":316}],"data":{}},{"key":"2ocoh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f0de3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bs22n","text":"III) Recipes ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8f6ge","text":"(Note: this is for a large batch; scale down as needed)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e6tje","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ao5t5","text":"A. Start with these parameters : 300 min buildup time,100 MHz sweepwidth, 25 mW power","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3nnis","text":"    b. Recommended to do a coarse frequency sweep (5 MHz resolution) to capture full lobe of sweep curve,                   then do a fine frequency sweep (2-­‐3 MHz resolution) to identify maximum amplitude","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ld0r","text":"    c. If polarizer contains background signal, perform a sweep using same parameters prior to loading sample","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6g05m","text":"    d. Perform routine sweeps every 2-‐3 months","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"35ck8","text":" 3. Start polarization at optimal microwave frequency, monitor buildup using RINMR program","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"31bjo","text":" 4. Note the following parameters, compare with historic values:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ki1i","text":"    a. Microwave frequency","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"850u1","text":"    b.Buildup curve maximum amplitude (solid state build-up)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63o7p","text":"    c. Buildup curve time constant (Typical time-constant in HyperSense 957 seconds)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"57fu1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"87m7f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2t54e","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":34,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bgdus","text":"B) HP dynamic 13C­ NMR spectroscopy to measure % polarization, T1:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":3},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":66},{"style":"sup","offset":14,"length":2},{"style":"sub","offset":64,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5kafm","text":"Prepare NMR spectrometer for HP polarization and T1 measurement:","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":50,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7nhvq","text":"    a. Insert sample with similar ionic strength, tune coils (1H,13C) and shim","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":62,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":65,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tdt5","text":"    b. Set up arrayed 13C sequence, verify that it runs properly. Spectral width to cover the signal of interest (Pyruvate at 171 ppm and Urea at 163.5 ppm) ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f0k4a","text":"        ii. Transmit + receive frequency  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8fq1b","text":"        iii. Pulsewidth + power for a low flip angle pulse (5 - 15°)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6qatd","text":"        iv. Acquire multiple transients to capture the entire relaxation of the HP signal","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ga62","text":"2. Prepare empty NMR tube with cap for measurement","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5k0dn","text":"3. Prepare polarizer for dissolution, inject dissolution buffer, dissolute. Note the time of start of dissolution","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eb70c","text":"4. Quickly inject HP dissolution into NMR tube, insert into spectrometer, start sequence","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ap0s","text":"5. Use timer to record transfer time from polarizer to spectrometer","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdprd","text":"6. TR = 5 * T1 (Pyruvate is ~ 48 s and Urea is ~44 s @ 11.7 T or measured in HP dynamic spectra section IV.D.1)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":17,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"relo","text":"    b. Alternatively, add 1/100 volume of   Gd-DOTA to reduce required TR","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":35,"offset":42,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3urhp","text":"    c.
